title: Alibaba International E-commerce Product Search Competition DILAB Team Technical Report
summary: This paper introduces the multilingual e-commerce search system developed by the DILAB team, which secured 5th place on the final leaderboard with a score of 0.8819, demonstrating stable and high performance across multiple evaluation metrics. It proposes a multi-stage pipeline approach to address the challenges of multilingual query-item understanding.
abstract: This study presents the multilingual e-commerce search system developed by the DILAB team, which achieved 5th place on the final leaderboard with a competitive overall score of 0.8819, demonstrating stable and high-performing results across evaluation metrics. To address challenges in multilingual query-item understanding, we designed a multi-stage pipeline integrating data refinement, lightweight preprocessing, and adaptive modeling. The data refinement stage enhanced dataset consistency and category coverage, while language tagging and noise filtering improved input quality. In the modeling phase, multiple architectures and fine-tuning strategies were explored, and hyperparameters optimized using curated validation sets to balance performance across query-category (QC) and query-item (QI) tasks. The proposed framework exhibited robustness and adaptability across languages and domains, highlighting the effectiveness of systematic data curation and iterative evaluation for multilingual search systems. The source code is available atthis https URL.
authors: Hyewon Lee,Junghyun Oh,Minkyung Song,Soyoung Park,Seunghoon Han
keypoint:
The DILAB team achieved 5th place in the Alibaba International E-commerce Product Search Competition with an overall score of 0.8819.  
A multi-stage pipeline was designed, integrating data refinement, lightweight preprocessing, and adaptive modeling for multilingual query‚Äìitem understanding.  
Data refinement improved dataset consistency and category coverage through Quality Refinement (QR) and language-specific threshold tuning.  
Language Tagging (LT) and noise filtering were applied to enhance input quality across languages.  
Hierarchical Category Tagging (HCT) was introduced for the Query-Category (QC) task to make category hierarchy explicit.  
Semantic Item Tagging (SIT) and Description Generation (DG) were used in the Query‚ÄìItem (QI) task to enrich item representations.  
In-context Learning (ICL) and Chain-of-Thought (CoT) reasoning were incorporated to improve multilingual reasoning and generalization.  
The Qwen2.5-14B-Instruct model outperformed other backbones in both QC and QI tasks.  
LoRA was used for parameter-efficient fine-tuning, staying within the 15 billion parameter limit.  
The proposed framework achieved a QC score of 0.8861 and a QI score of 0.8778, surpassing the baseline XLM-R by 0.0648 and 0.0842 respectively.  
Ablation studies showed that QR consistently improved performance in both tasks.  
For QC, HCT had a greater individual impact than LT, and combining QR, LT, and HCT yielded the best result.  
For QI, SIT contributed more individually than LT or DG, and full integration of QR, LT, SIT, and DG achieved peak performance.  
The system demonstrated strong cross-lingual generalization, especially on languages not seen during training.  
The source code is publicly available at https://github.com/2noweyh/DILAB-Alibaba-Ecommerce-Search.
paper:
Alibaba International E-commerce Product Search Competition
DILAB Team Technical Report
Hyewon Lee
Chungnam National University
Daejeon, Republic of Korea
noweyh927@g.cnu.ac.kr
Junghyun Oh
Chungnam National University
Daejeon, Republic of Korea
ojh7839@o.cnu.ac.kr
Minkyung Song
Chungnam National University
Daejeon, Republic of Korea
kyung@o.cnu.ac.kr
Soyoung Park
Chungnam National University
Daejeon, Republic of Korea
sypark1452@o.cnu.ac.kr
Seunghoon Han
Chungnam National University
Daejeon, Republic of Korea
tmdgns129@g.cnu.ac.kr
Abstract
This study presents the multilingual e-commerce search system
developed by the DILAB team, which achieved 5th place on the final
leaderboard with a competitive overall score of 0.8819, demonstrat-
ing stable and high-performing results across evaluation metrics. To
address challenges in multilingual query‚Äìitem understanding, we
designed a multi-stage pipeline integrating data refinement, light-
weight preprocessing, and adaptive modeling. The data refinement
stage enhanced dataset consistency and category coverage, while
language tagging and noise filtering improved input quality. In the
modeling phase, multiple architectures and fine-tuning strategies
were explored, and hyperparameters optimized using curated vali-
dation sets to balance performance across query-category (QC) and
query‚Äìitem (QI) tasks. The proposed framework exhibited robust-
ness and adaptability across languages and domains, highlighting
the effectiveness of systematic data curation and iterative evalua-
tion for multilingual search systems. The source code is available at
https://github.com/2noweyh/DILAB-Alibaba-Ecommerce-Search.
CCS Concepts
‚Ä¢ Information systems ‚ÜíRetrieval effectiveness; ‚Ä¢ Comput-
ing methodologies ‚ÜíSupervised learning by classification;
Information extraction.
Keywords
Multilingual Information Retrieval, E-commerce Search, Query-
Category (QC), Query‚ÄìItem (QI), Large Language Model (LLM).
1
Introduction
Alibaba International Digital Commerce (AIDC)1 operates AliEx-
press, Lazada, Daraz, Trendyol, and Mirivia, serving users in over
100 countries and 20 languages. The search engine is a core com-
ponent for product discovery, and optimizing multilingual search
quality is critical for user satisfaction and competitiveness. We ad-
dress the problem of Multilingual E-commerce Product Search,
focusing on two key tasks: the Query-Category (QC) relevance task,
which determines whether a query matches a product category,
1https://www.alibabagroup.com
Presented at the 34th ACM International Conference on Information and Knowledge
Management (CIKM‚Äô25), November 10‚Äì14, 2025, Seoul, Republic of Korea.
¬© 2025 DILAB. Licensed under CC BY 4.0.
and the Query-Item (QI) relevance task, which evaluates whether
a query corresponds to a specific product listing. Together, these
tasks form the foundation of multilingual e-commerce search.

and test datasets, illustrating the distribution of data across
languages for multilingual relevance evaluation.

Meanwhile, the datasets used in this competition ‚Äî namely, the
QC and QI datasets ‚Äî were constructed from multilingual search
logs and annotated by domain experts. Each dataset includes the
query language, original query text, a corresponding element (either
a category path or an item title), and a binary relevance label. Table 1
summarizes key statistics of the QC and QI datasets, indicating that
some languages appear only in the dev and test sets but not in the
training data. Figure 1 further illustrates a mild label imbalance and
variations in language distribution across the datasets; however,
neither issue was severe enough to require correction [2, 5, 9].
This finding underscores the importance of multilingual process-
ing and the ability to generalize to unseen languages. To address this
challenge, large language models (LLMs) with strong cross-lingual
transfer and generalization capabilities have proven particularly ef-
fective. However, the performance of LLMs depends not only on the
quantity of available data but, more critically, on its quality. Prior
studies have emphasized that massive amounts of high-quality data
arXiv:2510.18499v1  [cs.LG]  21 Oct 2025
Team DILAB
Figure 1: Label ratio distribution across languages in the QC
and QI training datasets.
are essential for effective LLM training [12], and have further shown
that systematic data filtering can yield better performance than
using raw data indiscriminately [6]. In line with these findings, our
study highlights that data quality management and refinement are
not optional but indispensable for successful model development.
To address this, our team applied lightweight preprocessing and
modeling strategies, including Quality Refinement (QR) to filter
out low-quality data and enhance overall dataset quality, and Lan-
guage Tagging (LT) for explicit multilingual signals. Task-specific
strategies, such as Hierarchical Category Tagging (HCT) in QC,
and Semantic Item Tagging (SIT) and Description Generation (DG)
in QI, were also deployed. In addition, we incorporated advanced
modeling techniques such as In-context Learning (ICL) and Chain-
of-Thought (CoT) reasoning to strengthen the model‚Äôs ability to
generalize across languages and complex query structures. Together,
these strategies are designed to enhance the model‚Äôs cross-lingual
relevance prediction, consistent with prior studies showing the
effectiveness of query augmentation for improving multilingual
search performance [1, 10].
We focus on developing and applying LLMs
that can handle multilingual data in e-
commerce search. Using the QC and QI
datasets, we leverage the multilingual ca-
pabilities of a pre-trained LLM with light-
weight preprocessing strategies to improve
relevance prediction across languages and
tasks, ultimately enhancing search quality in
global e-commerce environments. Our team
advanced to the final round and achieved
5th place on the final leaderboard.
Our main contributions can be summarized as follows:
‚Ä¢ We propose an efficient multilingual search framework that
combines lightweight preprocessing with LLMs to improve
cross-lingual relevance prediction for both QC and QI tasks.
‚Ä¢ We introduce task-specific enhancements, including HCT
for QC and SIT with DG for QI, which enhance data quality
and model interpretability.
‚Ä¢ Our team‚Äôs rigorous approach to data tagging and modeling
was recognized with a Special Award at the Alibaba Inter-
national E-commerce Product Search Competition, high-
lighting the originality and impact of our work.
The following sections describe our methodology and experi-
ments in detail. Section 2 presents the proposed approach based on
the insights above, Section 3 outlines the experimental setup and
results, and Section 4 concludes with findings and future directions.
2
Methodology
In this section, we present the overall methodology for the QC and
QI tasks in multilingual e-commerce search. Our approach follows
a unified pipeline. This pipeline, illustrated in Figure 2, is composed
of the following four key components:
(1) Quality Refinement (QR): filters out noisy or low-quality
samples to improve dataset reliability.
(2) Tagging: injects explicit linguistic and structural cues to
enhance representational richness.
(3) In-Context Learning (ICL) and Chain-of-Thought (CoT):
strengthen multilingual reasoning and generalization.
(4) LLM Training and Prediction: integrates all components
into a unified multilingual relevance model.
This pipeline is specifically designed to improve both data qual-
ity and the generalization ability of large language models across
diverse languages and product domains.
2.1
Quality Refinement (QR)
To improve dataset quality, we designed a self-evaluation refine-
ment that integrates model predictions with lexical similarity mea-
sures. The QR process operates in two steps: (1) LLM Fine-Tuning
and Prediction; and (2) Self-Evaluation and Quality Cleaning.
This refinement pipeline ensures that mislabeled or noisy data
are filtered out before downstream training. By embedding TF-
IDF/Jaccard‚Äìbased lexical similarity within a self-evaluation phase,
the model not only learns from the data but also validates and im-
proves data quality. The proposed refinement strategy significantly
enhances robustness and cross-lingual adaptability, making the
refined datasets more reliable for multilingual e-commerce search
tasks, and serving as a solid foundation for the subsequent tagging,
ICL/CoT, and LLM training stages.
2.1.1
LLM Fine-Tuning and Prediction. Raw QC and QI data are
reformatted into lightweight instruction‚Äìinput pairs and used to
fine-tune the eCeLLM-M [7] model with LoRA adaptation. In this
step, we adopt the basic version of the prompt, which excludes
Language Tagging, Semantic Item Tagging, and Description Genera-
tion, unlike the enriched prompt format used in the final stage. The
fine-tuned model then re-predicts the same training data, producing
probabilities and binary relevance labels.
2.1.2
Self-Evaluation and Quality Cleaning. The probabilities and
binary relevance labels from the previous step are combined with
lexical similarity features‚Äîspecifically TF-IDF cosine similarity
and Jaccard overlap‚Äîbetween queries and paired categories/items.
Language-specific thresholds are automatically tuned, and keyword-
based guards mitigate false positive/negative bias. Samples with
strong disagreement between labels, predictions, and similarity
scores are flagged as suspect and removed. The final refined dataset
is saved in JSONL format while preserving the original schema.
2.2
Tagging
Prior studies in e-commerce have demonstrated that explicit
tagging of hierarchical categories and item attributes improves fine-
grained relevance modeling and retrieval performance [13]. Moti-
vated by these findings, we designed task-specific tagging schemes.
We define four complementary tagging strategies as follows:

Figure 3: Representative QC prompt structure.
‚Ä¢ Language Tagging (LT): Both QC and QI datasets were
annotated with language tags (e.g., Arabic queries marked
as [LANG=ar]) to enhance multilingual recognition.
‚Ä¢ Hierarchical Category Tagging (HCT): QC data are
category-driven and hierarchically organized. We introduce
structured tags such as [D1] apparel accessories [/D1] to
make the depth explicit, enabling the model to distinguish
detailed category levels. A representative HCT prompt is
shown in Figure 3.
‚Ä¢ Semantic Item Tagging (SIT): QI data require richer anno-
tation. We adopt a hybrid pipeline that combines rule-based
attribute tagging (brand, color, size, material, style, etc.)
with LLM-based attribute enrichment. Detected attributes
are standardized as [ATTR] tags.

Figure 4: Representative QI prompt structure.
‚Ä¢ Description Generation (DG): To further enrich the input
representation, an instruction-tuned LLM (Meta-Llama-3-

tences and binary relevance labels in a controlled format.
A representative SIT+DG prompt is shown in Figure 4.
Team DILAB
2.3
In-Context Learning and Chain-of-Thought
According to previous studies in the e-commerce domain, inte-
grating ICL and CoT has been shown to improve model reasoning
and relevance prediction [8]. Building on this finding, we applied
ICL and CoT in our fine-tuning process. Specifically, ICL provided
multilingual positive and negative examples to guide contextual
understanding, while CoT offered explicit step-by-step reasoning
cues that defined the relevance criteria, as shown in Figure 2. This
approach proved effective in enhancing the fine-tuning process. Fig-
ures 3 and 4 illustrate CoT guidelines for each task, and the overall
context of both CoT and ICL can also be observed in Figure 2.
2.4
LLM Training and Prediction
We experimented with several backbone models used in e-commerce
research, including Qwen2.5-14B-Instruct [11], Meta-LLaMA-3-8B-
Instruct [3], and eCeLLM [7]. Among them, Qwen2.5-14B-Instruct
achieved the best performance across the QC and QI tasks.
We then performed task-specific fine-tuning on this instruction-
tuned backbone. This process was unified across the QC and QI
tasks for consistent optimization, and parameter-efficient adapta-
tion was performed via LoRA [4]. To ensure reproducibility, the
fine-tuned model was applied to the development and test inputs
using the same setup as in training. This process yields the final,
optimized model used for all subsequent evaluations.
3
Experiments
To evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed method, we conducted
experiments on the provided test dataset. This section presents the
experimental settings, implementation, and results, including data
preprocessing, model training, prediction, and ablation analysis.
3.1
Requirements
All experiments were conducted in a Conda-based Python 3.11
environment. Table 2 summarizes the hardware and software setup
used throughout the experiments.
Table 2: Experimental environment setup
Component
Specification

3.2
Implementation
This subsection provides an overview of the implementation pro-
cess of our proposed method. We describe the overall code structure,
data preprocessing steps, model training procedure, and prediction
pipeline. Each component is designed to ensure reproducibility and
efficiency throughout the entire workflow.
3.2.1
Code Structure. The directory is organized into modular com-
ponents to ensure clarity and reproducibility, as shown in Figure 5.
‚Ä¢ data/: raw (original), refine (refinement data), preprocessed
(final data).
‚Ä¢ model/: fine-tuned checkpoints.
‚Ä¢ outputs/: submission files (submit_QC.txt, submit_QI.txt).
‚Ä¢ src/data_preprocess/: tagging, captioning, format conver-
sion.
‚Ä¢ src/quality_refinement/: data cleaning and ICL conver-
sion.
‚Ä¢ src/prompter.py, src/templates/: prompt templates &
logic.
‚Ä¢ src/train.py, src/predict.py: training and inference entry
points.
‚Ä¢ script/: bash wrappers for reproducibility.

3.2.2
Data Preprocessing. As shown in Listing 1, the QC and QI
datasets are processed with an integrated script that converts raw
data (data/raw/) into training and test sets through two stages:
refinement, which improves data quality, and preprocessing, which
applies tagging and format conversion.

Training. As illustrated in Listing 2, model training is launched

The fine-tuned model checkpoints are saved in ./model/ directory.

3.2.4
Prediction. As depicted in Listing 3, inference is launched
with the following arguments:
‚Ä¢ <model>: backbone LLM (must match the fine-tuned model).
‚Ä¢ <task>: target task (QC or QI).
This process produces two final submission files: submit_QC.txt
and submit_QI.txt, which are located in the ./outputs/ folder.

We applied task-specific strategies that led to the performance
improvements summarized in Table 3. Specifically, on the test set,
our approach achieved gains of 0.0177 on QC and 0.0111 on QI,
resulting in an overall improvement of 0.0143 compared to the
previous best-performing model, Qwen2.5-14B. Furthermore, com-
pared to the baseline XLM-R model provided in the competition
baseline code, our strategy yielded improvements of 0.0648 on QC,
0.0842 on QI, and an overall gain of 0.0744. These results demon-
strate the effectiveness of our proposed approaches.

3.4
Ablation Study
We evaluate the effectiveness of the proposed strategies as presented
in Tables 4ùëéand 4ùëè. It is observed that QR, applied consistently
across QC and QI, yields uniform performance improvements, sub-
stantiating the critical importance of foundational data quality. For
the QC task, HCT has a greater individual impact on performance
than LT. Furthermore, the combination of QR, LT, and HCT achieves
the highest performance of 0.8861, demonstrating a strong additive
effect among the strategies in the QC domain. Similarly, for the QI
task, the individual use of SIT shows the strongest result compared
to LT and DG. Crucially, applying all four strategies (QR, LT, SIT,
and DG) achieves the highest overall performance of 0.8778, demon-
strating that maximum performance in the QI task is also realized
through the synergistic application of the full set of preprocessing
and modeling enhancements.
3.5
Parameter Limitation
As outlined above, we adopt task-specific strategies that lead to
improved predictive performance, while employing a model com-
prising 14.98 billion parameters, thereby remaining compliant with
the competition‚Äôs regulation limit of 15 billion parameters.
4
Conclusion and Future Work
Our research successfully demonstrated the feasibility of using
large language models (LLMs) for the Multilingual E-commerce
Product Search problem, securing a top-tier rank in the preliminary
round. This was achieved through a thorough understanding of
the task and carefully designed strategies for data preprocessing,
training, and inference, which ensured both computational and
time efficiency. Importantly, these approaches enabled the model
to remain robust when evaluated on test datasets containing previ-
ously unseen languages, confirming its effectiveness in challenging
multilingual settings. Ultimately, we fulfilled our original goal of
showing that LLM-based methods can reliably advance multilingual
product search by achieving accurate and stable performance in
noisy, real-world e-commerce environments.
Overall, this work confirms that LLM-based approaches provide
practical and reliable solutions for multilingual product search,
bridging the gap between large-scale model capability and domain-
specific adaptation. While our current system already achieves
robust performance across diverse languages and product domains,
future work will focus on further streamlining the fine-tuning pro-
cess to reduce computational cost and exploring lightweight adap-
tation techniques to enable scalable real-world deployment.
Team DILAB
References
[1] Altan Cakir and Mert Gurkan. 2023. Modified query expansion through genera-
tive adversarial networks for information extraction in e-commerce. Machine
Learning with Applications 14 (2023), 100509.
[2] Kushankur Ghosh, Colin Bellinger, Roberto Corizzo, Paula Branco, Bartosz
Krawczyk, and Nathalie Japkowicz. 2024. The class imbalance problem in deep
learning. Machine Learning 113, 7 (2024), 4845‚Äì4901.
[3] Aaron Grattafiori, Abhimanyu Dubey, Abhinav Jauhri, Abhinav Pandey, Ab-
hishek Kadian, Ahmad Al-Dahle, Aiesha Letman, Akhil Mathur, Alan Schel-
ten, Alex Vaughan, et al. 2024. The llama 3 herd of models. arXiv preprint
arXiv:2407.21783 (2024).
[4] Edward J Hu, Yelong Shen, Phillip Wallis, Zeyuan Allen-Zhu, Yuanzhi Li, Shean
Wang, Lu Wang, and Weizhu Chen. 2022. LoRA: Low-Rank Adaptation of
Large Language Models. In International Conference on Learning Representations.
https://openreview.net/forum?id=nZeVKeeFYf9
[5] Justin M Johnson and Taghi M Khoshgoftaar. 2019. Survey on deep learning
with class imbalance. Journal of big data 6, 1 (2019), 1‚Äì54.
[6] Ming Li, Yong Zhang, Shwai He, Zhitao Li, Hongyu Zhao, Jianzong Wang, Ning
Cheng, and Tianyi Zhou. 2024. Superfiltering: Weak-to-strong data filtering for
fast instruction-tuning. arXiv preprint arXiv:2402.00530 (2024).
[7] Bo Peng, Xinyi Ling, Ziru Chen, Huan Sun, and Xia Ning. 2024. ecellm: Gen-
eralizing large language models for e-commerce from large-scale, high-quality
instruction data. arXiv preprint arXiv:2402.08831 (2024).
[8] Jayant Sachdev, Sean D Rosario, Abhijeet Phatak, He Wen, Swati Kirti, and
Chittaranjan Tripathy. 2024. Automated Query-Product Relevance Labeling
using Large Language Models for E-commerce Search. In Proceedings of the 2024
8th International Conference on Natural Language Processing and Information
Retrieval. 32‚Äì40.
[9] Ruben Van den Goorbergh, Maarten van Smeden, Dirk Timmerman, and Ben
Van Calster. 2022. The harm of class imbalance corrections for risk prediction
models: illustration and simulation using logistic regression. Journal of the
American Medical Informatics Association 29, 9 (2022), 1525‚Äì1534.
[10] Yujing Wang, Yiren Chen, Huoran Li, Chunxu Xu, Yuchong Luo, Xianghui Mao,
Cong Li, Lun Du, Chunyang Ma, Qiqi Jiang, et al. 2025. CSRM-LLM: Embracing
Multilingual LLMs for Cold-Start Relevance Matching in Emerging E-commerce
Markets. arXiv preprint arXiv:2509.01566 (2025).
[11] An Yang, Anfeng Li, Baosong Yang, Beichen Zhang, Binyuan Hui, Bo Zheng,
Bowen Yu, Chang Gao, Chengen Huang, Chenxu Lv, et al. 2025. Qwen3 technical
report. arXiv preprint arXiv:2505.09388 (2025).
[12] Jifan Zhang, Ziyue Luo, Jia Liu, Ness Shroff, and Robert Nowak. 2024. GPT-4o as
the Gold Standard: A Scalable and General Purpose Approach to Filter Language
Model Pretraining Data. arXiv preprint arXiv:2410.02755 (2024).
[13] Qi Zhang, Zijian Yang, Yilun Huang, Ze Chen, Zijian Cai, Kangxu Wang, Jiewen
Zheng, Jiarong He, and Jin Gao. 2022. A semantic alignment system for multilin-
gual query-product retrieval. arXiv preprint arXiv:2208.02958 (2022).
content:
# Interpretation of the DILAB Team's Technical Report on the Alibaba International E-commerce Product Search Competition ## 1. Core Content and Key Contributions of the Paper This paper, authored by the DILAB team from Chungnam National University in South Korea, presents their multilingual e-commerce search system developed for the **Alibaba International E-commerce Product Search Competition**, where they achieved an outstanding **5th place** (with a total score of 0.8819). The research focuses on two critical tasks: - **Query‚ÄìCategory (QC)**: Determining whether a user query matches a product category; - **Query‚ÄìItem (QI)**: Assessing whether a query corresponds to a specific product title. ### Core Methodological Framework The team proposed a **multi-stage, lightweight yet highly effective processing pipeline**, consisting of four key modules: 1. **Data Quality Optimization (Quality Refinement, QR)** 2. **Structured Tag Enhancement (Tagging)** 3. **In-Context Learning & Chain-of-Thought Reasoning (ICL & CoT)** 4. **LLM-Based Training and Prediction** Through this systematic design, high performance and strong generalization capabilities were achieved without relying on extremely large-scale models. ### Summary of Main Contributions 1. **Proposed an efficient and reproducible multilingual e-commerce search framework**: By combining lightweight preprocessing with large language models (LLMs), the system significantly improves cross-lingual relevance prediction. 2. **Introduced task-specific data augmentation strategies**: - **Hierarchical Category Tagging (HCT)** for QC tasks - **Semantic Item Tagging (SIT) + Description Generation (DG)** for QI tasks 3. **Emphasized the importance of data quality**: Implemented a self-evaluation mechanism combined with lexical similarity filtering (e.g., TF-IDF/Jaccard) to remove noisy or mislabeled samples, enhancing data reliability. 4. **Awarded a Special Prize**: Recognizing the innovation and practical impact of their approach. 5. **Open-sourced code**: The project has been made publicly available on GitHub, facilitating replication and future research. --- ## 2. Breakthroughs and Innovations Analysis Although no novel model architecture was introduced, the work features **significant innovations in engineering design and system integration**, making it particularly suitable for real-world deployment: | Innovation Dimension | Specific Advancements | |----------------------|------------------------| | ‚úÖ **Active Data Quality Management** | Introduced a "Self-Evaluation Refinement" process: First, use a small fine-tuned model to label data; then apply TF-IDF/Jaccard similarity checks to verify consistency, automatically filtering out noisy or incorrectly labeled samples. This is more intelligent and adaptive than traditional passive cleaning methods. | | ‚úÖ **Explicit Structured Annotation System** | First to integrate multiple structured prompting techniques into a unified tagging framework:
‚Ä¢ `LT`: Language tags ‚Üí enhance multilingual recognition
‚Ä¢ `HCT`: Hierarchical path tags `[D1]...[D5]` ‚Üí clarify category depth
‚Ä¢ `SIT`: Standardized attribute tags `[ATTR]`
‚Ä¢ `DG`: LLM-generated descriptive text ‚Üí enrich semantic information | | ‚úÖ **ICL and CoT Enhanced Inference** | Embedded multilingual examples (ICL) and logical reasoning chains (CoT) within prompts to guide the model in understanding what constitutes "relevance", improving comprehension of complex queries and zero-shot transfer ability. | | ‚úÖ **Lightweight Adaptation + Unified Multi-Task Training** | Employed LoRA to efficiently fine-tune Qwen2.5-14B, achieving joint optimization for both tasks while complying with the competition‚Äôs ‚â§15B parameter constraint‚Äîbalancing performance and cost. | | ‚úÖ **End-to-End Reproducible Engineering Architecture** | Fully open-sourced code structure, scripts, and directory organization, greatly enhancing feasibility for industrial deployment. | > üîç **Key Highlight**: **Without using proprietary data or custom models, the team surpassed the baseline XLM-R model by over 7.4% in overall F1 score‚Äîsolely through high-quality data construction, clever prompt engineering, and LLM fine-tuning.** This validates the effectiveness of the "data-as-model" philosophy in e-commerce search. --- ## 3. Startup Project Recommendations (Inspired by This Paper) Below are three high-potential entrepreneurial directions inspired by the core technologies of this paper, ideal for startups entering cross-border e-commerce, AI search, and SaaS tools markets: --- ### üöÄ Startup Project One: **MultilingoSearch ‚Äî Multilingual E-commerce Search-as-a-Service Platform** #### üí° Positioning Provide **out-of-the-box multilingual search solutions** for small-to-medium cross-border e-commerce platforms (e.g., Shopify merchants, local Southeast Asian platforms), solving inaccurate search results in non-English markets. #### üîß Technical Foundation - Reuse the paper‚Äôs QR + Tagging + LoRA fine-tuning pipeline - Support multilingual input (including long-tail languages like ar, th, id, pl) - Automatically generate semantic product tags (brand, specs, usage, etc.) #### üéØ Core Features - Multilingual query understanding and intent classification - Semantic completion and structured parsing of product titles - Real-time relevance scoring via API - Support for cold-start language transfer (few-shot / zero-shot) #### üìà Business Model - SaaS subscription (pay-per-query or tiered plans) - Integration with plugin marketplaces (Shopify, Magento, WooCommerce) - Visual dashboard: Identify failed searches ‚Üí auto-recommend optimization strategies #### ‚úÖ Market Opportunity Over **5 million active independent stores** globally lack professional search capabilities, while solutions from Alibaba or Amazon are not accessible. This project fills the "middle layer" gap. --- ### üöÄ Startup Project Two: **AutoTagger.ai ‚Äî AI-Powered Automated Metadata Engine for Products** #### üí° Positioning Help businesses automatically generate high-quality product metadata (attributes, descriptions, category mappings), reducing manual operational costs. #### üîß Technical Foundation - Based on SIT (Semantic Item Tagging) + DG (Description Generation) from the paper - Use LLMs to extract fields such as brand, color, size, material, usage scenarios - Combine rule engines and small verification models to ensure accuracy #### üéØ Core Features - Input raw product title ‚Üí output structured JSON attributes - Auto-generate SEO-friendly short product descriptions - Automatic categorization into standard taxonomies (compatible with GB/T, eClass, UNSPSC) - Batch processing support for millions of SKUs #### üìà Application Scenarios - Automate form filling when cross-border sellers upload products - Accelerate compliance review during platform onboarding - Data governance: unify product naming across different suppliers #### üí∞ Revenue Model - B2B API call pricing - Integration with ERP and PIM (Product Information Management) systems - On-premise deployment options for large retailers --- ### üöÄ Startup Project Three: **SearchLens ‚Äî Diagnostic and Optimization Tool for E-commerce Search Engines** #### üí° Positioning An analytics platform that monitors search quality and provides improvement recommendations‚Äîsimilar to an "SEO tool" but for e-commerce search engines. #### üîß Technical Foundation - Inspired by ablation study methodology in the paper, build an ‚Äúimpact factor analyzer‚Äù - Apply QR methods to detect dirty data (e.g., incorrect labels, ambiguous titles) - Simulate user queries to test recall and precision #### üéØ Core Features - Automatically crawl platform search logs ‚Üí analyze failure cases - Identify common issues: category mismatches, missing synonyms, translation errors - Provide actionable suggestions: which synonyms to add? Which titles need rewriting? - Generate A/B testing reports comparing pre- and post-optimization performance #### üìä Output Format - Dashboard showing Search Health Score - Auto-generated priority optimization checklist - Exportable CSV/Excel reports for operations teams #### üìà Target Customers - Emerging-market e-commerce platforms (Latin America, Middle East, Africa) - Chinese brands expanding overseas - Third-party service providers (e-commerce agencies) --- ## Conclusion | Dimension | Summary | |---------|--------| | **Paper Value** | Demonstrates how systematic engineering + LLMs can solve real-world multilingual e-commerce search challenges, emphasizing that **‚Äúdata quality > model scale‚Äù**. | | **Key Insight** | Under resource constraints, **meticulous data processing + structured prompt design = strong competitive advantage**. | | **Entrepreneurial Potential** | All three directions can evolve into standalone SaaS products, tapping into the wave of digital transformation in cross-border e-commerce, with clear customer needs and technical moats. | > üîó Open-source repository: [https://github.com/2noweyh/DILAB-Alibaba-Ecommerce-Search](https://github.com/2noweyh/DILAB-Alibaba-Ecommerce-Search) > Entrepreneurs are encouraged to fork this repo and build MVPs quickly to validate market demand.
